Fig 21 Plan view showing how to determine average grade

When measuring daylight plane, height is measured from the average of the grade at the
midpoint of the building and the grade of the closest point on the abutting site.

For this side of this structure, the
average grade is the average
of the grades at these two

Certification of daylight plane compliance:

Upon request by the building official any person
building or making improvements to a structure shall
provide a certification that the structure, as built, com-
plies with the daylight plane provisions in Code Section
18.12.040(a). Such certification shall be prepared
by a licensed engineer, architect, or surveyor, and
shall be provided prior to frame inspection. (Sections
18.12.040(j)).

27

visual_elements.description: Figure 21 is a plan view diagram showing three adjacent lots to illustrate how to determine average grade. A central 'Subject House' lot is flanked by two 'Neighbor' lots. The diagram shows that for each side of the subject structure, the average grade is calculated from two points: one at the midpoint of the subject building's side wall and the other at the closest point on the abutting neighbor's site. These points are indicated by black dots, and lines connect them to callout boxes. The diagram labels 'Front yard', 'Rear yard', 'Interior-side yard', 'Buildable area', and shows a sidewalk and street running along the bottom edge.

A key or legend for Figure 21, located at the bottom left. It defines five symbols: a solid line for 'Lot line', a dashed line for 'Required setbacks', a grid of small squares for 'Sidewalk', a light grey shaded area for 'Buildable area', and a dark grey shaded area for 'Existing house'.

Figure 22 is a detailed cross-section diagram illustrating the rule for allowable eave protrusion. It shows a roof eave extending from a vertical 'wall plane'. A thick dashed diagonal line represents the 'daylight plane'. The diagram indicates that the eave can protrude a maximum of 2 feet from the wall plane. An annotation points out that 'The daylight plane must clear the point where the wall plane intersects the top of the roof material'.
A rectangular box with a light grey background containing regulatory text under the heading 'Certification of daylight plane compliance:'.

subheadings: Fig 21 Plan view showing how to determine average grade
Fig 22 Detail showing allowable eave protrusion

additional_notes: The page has a two-column layout. The left column contains Figure 21 and its key. The right column contains Figure 22 and a text box on compliance certification.
The page number '27' is located in the bottom right corner.
The document appears to be a clean scan or digital copy of a technical manual.
There are no handwritten annotations, stamps, or other markings on the page.
